bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 162, Number 106 (Friday, July 1, 2016)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. CROWLEY:H.R. 5614.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution[Page H4192]

item.title: Sustaining Healthcare Integrity and Fair Treatment Act of 2016

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

summary.text: This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to remove certain hospitals specializing in neoplastic disease from their classification as long-term care hospitals for purposes of Medicare payment. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services shall make payments to these hospitals under reasonable cost-based reimbursement rules rather than under the prospective payment system.

bill.title: To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to provide for a change in Medicare classification for certain hospitals.

item.title: To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to provide for a change in Medicare classification for certain hospitals.
To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to provide for a change in Medicare classification for certain hospitals.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
